pages:
Technical Assistance Report
 
 
Project Number: 41057 
April 2007  
 
 
 
A Program of Studies on the Development Experience 
of the People’s Republic of China and India 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FDI  –  foreign direct investment 
  ICRIER  –  Indian Council for Research and International Economic 
Relations  
  IPPS-PU  –  Institute of Public Policy Studies of Peking University 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management   
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, inclusive social development, and 
regional cooperation 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling environment, human 
development, and trade and investment 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice Presidents  L. Jin, Operations Group 1 
C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations Group 2 
Directors General  Kunio Senga, South Asia Department 
H. Satish Rao, East Asia Department 
   
Team leader  V. B. Tulasidhar, Senior Economist, Office of the Director General, East 
Asia Department  
Team members  P. Dayal, Principal Economist, India Resident Mission 
  M. Tang, Deputy Resident Representative, People’s Republic of China 
Resident Mission

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the 39th Annual Meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Hyderabad, India 
in May 2006, representatives of the Government of India suggested that ADB support studies 
on the development experience of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) in order to benefit 
India and other developing countries. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) of the Government of PRC 
supported  this  suggestion  and  also  expressed  its  interest  in  studying  India’s  development 
experience.  Further,  the  PRC’s  MOF  requested  a  tripartite  meeting  in  Beijing  with  the 
participation of ADB, India, and PRC to discuss the program of studies. Both PRC’s MOF and 
the MOF of the Government of India requested that ADB provide regional technical assistance 
(RETA) for conducting the studies. The underlying theme of this exchange of development 
experiences is to obtain an Indian perspective on PRC development experience through study 
by Indian think tanks and scholars and, likewise, to acquire a PRC perspective on Indian 
development experiences through study by PRC think tanks and scholars. 
 
2.  A meeting was organized in Beijing on 12 February 2007 to discuss the objective and 
broad scope of studies, implementation arrangements, tentative timetable, and possible ADB 
support for the program of studies. Attending the meeting were representatives of PRC’s MOF, 
the Indian Embassy in Beijing, the Institute of Public Policy Studies of Peking University (IPPS-
PU), the Indian Council for Research and International Economic Relations (ICRIER), and ADB. 
The participants decided to concentrate the studies on four sectors of strategic interest to each 
country. Key findings and insights from sector-level studies and the overall reform experiences 
of PRC and India will be further summarized in an analytical overview to draw lessons for other 
developing member countries (DMCs) and emerging middle-income countries.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  While the PRC and India are now among the fastest growing economies in the world, the 
drivers of economic growth, as well as its pattern and impact are not the same in the two 
countries. For instance, manufacturing exports driven by foreign direct investment (FDI) and 
massive  public  investments  in  infrastructure  have  been  the  main  driving  forces  of  PRC’s 
economy in recent years. In India, by contrast, FDI and public investment have played a 
relatively minor role. India has seen strong growth in the services sector that has been driven by 
internationally  competitive  native  firms.  Reforms  in  the  PRC  had  an  immediate  impact  on 
alleviating poverty in the early 1980s while India’s record in this has been more modest. 
 
4.  The diverse and rich development experiences of these two countries emanate from 
differences in their economic policies and systems, as well as their social diversities. Yet, the 
development  challenges  facing  the  PRC  and  India  are  similar  and  daunting.  Some  key 
challenges  include:  continued  dependence  of  large  proportions  of  the  populations  on 
subsistence agriculture, creating viable employment for the large underemployed labor forces, 
migration  to  urban  areas,  social  tensions  during  transition,  energy  security,  environmental 
degradation, and management of scarce natural resources—particularly water. In the face of 
these  difficulties,  an  additional  challenge  is  to  maintain  sufficient  momentum  in  economic 
reforms to improve the efficiency of markets. The PRC and India can learn from one another 
and from their rich development experiences with the aim of meeting their common challenges. 
More importantly, the development experiences of these two countries will be of strategic and 
practical interest to other DMCs and emerging middle-income countries in the region.

2     
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
5.  The RETA will help the PRC and India to implement a program of studies on their 
development  experiences.  Both  governments  consider  the  program  of  immense  strategic 
importance and practical use to them as well as to other emerging middle-income countries in 
the region. The RETA will be implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will focus on in-depth sector 
and country-level studies of interest to the PRC and India. Phase 2 will focus on summarizing 
the  technical  assistance  (TA)  findings  to  draw  lessons  for  other  DMCs  and  on  their 
dissemination. The TA’s design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The RETA is expected to improve awareness among policy and opinion makers in the 
PRC and India about one another’s development experience in selected sectors and areas. This 
would lead to improved collaboration between the PRC and India on development policy issues 
in the selected sectors. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The RETA will conduct studies on, and facilitate dissemination in the Asia-Pacific region 
of, lessons from the PRC’s and India’s development experiences. To achieve this, the TA will be 
implemented in two phases. Phase 1 will consist of (i) conducting in-depth studies to analyze 
the development experience in sectors of strategic interest to the PRC and India and on the 
overall progress of economic reforms, and (ii) drawing lessons from the in-depth studies for 
development policy. Phase 2 will focus on widely disseminating the findings. The RETA will 
have four major outputs:  
 
(i)  Analytical overview of overall reform experience of India and in-depth studies in 
four sectors or areas of interest to the Government of the PRC. Tentatively, these 
sectors and areas are: (a) the professional and higher education sector and its 
contribution to economic growth; (b) growth of the services sector, with special 
focus on information technology; (c) growth of internationally competitive local 
entrepreneurship; and (d) the financial sector, capital market reforms, and growth 
in  the  use  of  sophisticated  financial  instruments.  The  output  includes 
dissemination of these findings in the PRC. 
(ii)  Analytical overview of overall reform experience of the PRC and in-depth studies 
in four sectors or areas of interest to the Government of India. Tentatively, these 
sectors and areas are: (a) FDI-funded and export-oriented mass manufacturing, 
(b)  labor  sector  reforms,  (c)  financing  and  implementation  of  infrastructure 
projects, and (d) state-owned enterprise reforms and restructuring. The output 
includes dissemination of these findings in India. 
(iii)  Based on the findings of the eight studies, identification of potential areas for 
cooperation in development policy between the PRC and India. 
(iv)  A concise analytical report that is based on in-depth sector studies of PRC and 
Indian  development  experiences,  as  well  as  on  wider  developmental  policy 
issues  of  interest  to  other  DMCs1 and  middle-income  countries.  The  output 
includes wide dissemination of the study findings. 
 
                                                 
1  In particular, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Nepal, Pakistan, the Philippines, and Viet Nam.

3
C.  Cost and Financing 
8.  The total cost of the proposed RETA, estimated at $954,000, will be financed by a grant 
from ADB’s TA funding program. The RETA proceeds will cover consulting services, exchange 
visits by scholars, regional meetings, international travel, publications, as well as seminar and 
workshop costs. The detailed cost estimates for the proposed RETA are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
9.  The MOFs of the PRC and India, in consultation with ADB, identified the IPPS-PU to 
conduct  such  studies  for  the  PRC  and  the  ICRIER  to  conduct  the  studies  for  India.  The 
selections were made on mutual understanding between ADB and the governments, based on 
the following broad criteria: (i) experience in conducting research and training in the areas of 
public policy and international economic relations, (ii) international reputation for research and 
training capabilities, (iii) strong and experienced faculty and adequate research infrastructure, 
and (iv) stature and experience for providing independent advice to the government. 
 
10.  Both  the  governments  endorsed  the  RETA  which  will  be  supervised  by  a  steering 
committee  comprising  two  representatives  from  each  government  and  from  ADB. 2  All 
consultants  for  the  RETA  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines.3 Where 
procurement will be necessary under the RETA, that also will be in accordance with ADB 
guidelines.4 ADB will be the executing agency for the RETA. The IPPS-PU and ICRIER will be 
engaged by ADB on a single source selection basis.  
11.  The IPPS-PU was established as the national center for research and training in the 
area  of  public  policy  at  Peking  University.  The  IPPS-PU  has  a  core  faculty  of  15  senior 
professors. This multidisciplinary institution supplements its core faculty by drawing eminent and 
experienced faculty from the various departments of Peking University, from senior government 
policymakers, and from other national-level institutions. ICRIER is one of India’s premier policy 
research institutions. It has six key areas: strategic aspects of India’s external relations, regional 
and bilateral issues, issues related to the World Trade Organization, global financial integration, 
international trade, and macroeconomic management. It has a permanent faculty of 17 scholars 
and draws on external expertise in both academia and government. The Institute has good 
experience providing policy advice to governments. 
12.  In  Phase  1,  the  country-level  in-depth  studies  will  be  carried  out  by  IPPS-PU  and 
ICRIER. PRC scholars will study the sectors of their interest in India with assistance from 
ICRIER. Similarly, Indian scholars will carry out the studies on the PRC with assistance from 
IPPS-PU. Each institution will produce a two-part report. The first part will provide an overview 
of reforms in the country. The second part of the report will contain in-depth studies on selected 
sectors and provide an assessment of the potential and areas for bilateral cooperation. The 
sector reports will also include sector-level policy briefs. The results of the sector studies will be 
disseminated  in  both  countries.  These  tasks  will  be  accomplished  under  a  collaboration 
framework to be agreed during the scoping workshop (see paragraph 15). The framework will 
provide details regarding the exchange visits, sharing of data and information, peer review of 
                                                 
2  Represented  by the East  Asia Department, the South Asia Department, and the Economic and Research 
Department. 
3  ADB. 2007. Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by ADB and Its Borrowers (April 2006, as amended from time to 
time). Manila. 
4  ADB. 2007. Procurement Guidelines (April 2006, as amended from time to time). Manila.

4     
papers for quality control, consultative processes,5 and other administrative arrangements. The 
broad terms of reference for these two institutions are in Appendix 3. The study design is shown 
schematically in Appendix 4.  
13.  Phase 2 of the TA will focus on (i) preparing a concise analytical summary of the findings 
from the in-depth sector studies done in Phase 1 and drawing inferences for development policy 
in  other  DMCs  and  middle-income  countries  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  (ii)  disseminate 
development lessons from the PRC and India in other DMCs, and (iii) publish the TA findings. 
Data collected under the TA will be made accessible for further research. ADB will take the lead 
in implementing Phase 2. 
14.  An international development specialist will help the steering committee supervise the 
program of studies and coordinate the activities of ICRIER and IPPS-PU. The development 
specialist will participate in all key activities of the TA, will be responsible for preparing the 
concise analytical summary of country-level studies in Phase 2, and will ensure the quality of TA 
outputs in Phase 1. This specialist will be engaged intermittently for 7 person-months during the 
course of the study. National coordination specialists will be engaged intermittently for a period 
of 7 months to assist ADB and the international development specialist.6 Detailed terms of 
reference for these consultants are in Appendix 3. 
15.  Soon after approval of the RETA, a scoping workshop will be held to (i) firm up the 
understandings reached on the sectors to be studied in each country; (ii) determine the detailed 
scope of coverage of each sector study, including the terms of reference for the writers of 
individual  papers;  (iii)  agree  on  the  collaboration  framework  between  the  institutions;  (iv) 
determine the procedure for reviewing the progress of studies and their quality; (v) agree on the 
outline of the final study; (vi) discuss options for effective dissemination of TA findings; and (vii) 
discuss other administrative arrangements. Both the participating institutions, members of the 
steering committee, and ADB will participate in this workshop. 
16.  The RETA is expected to be completed in 12 months, which includes 8 months for 
Phase 1 and 4 months for Phase 2. The RETA will aim to commission sector studies in July 
2007 and complete them by March 2008. Phase 2 could commence in March 2008 and end in 
June 2008. Presentations under this phase would include a seminar during the ADB Annual 
Meeting in 2008, to be followed by dissemination in DMCs in June 2008.  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $954,000 on a grant basis for 
A Program of Studies on the Development Experience of the People’s Republic of China and 
India, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
5  It is proposed to organize, as required, (i) midterm workshops to assess and discuss the progress of work of 
individual studies and their methodologies in order to take remedial measures, and (ii) final workshops to present 
TA outputs to a cross section of stakeholders in order to seek their views for incorporating into the final reports.  
6  These specialists will be recruited as individual consultants.

8  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Development Specialist (7 person-months) 
1.  The specialist will assist the steering committee in coordinating and in supervising the 
activities of other consultants. He or she will participate in all key activities of the technical 
assistance (TA). The consultant will prepare a concise analytical overview of TA findings and be 
responsible  for  ensuring  the  quality  of  TA  outputs,  which  will  also  be  peer-reviewed.  The 
consultant will provide inputs intermittently—part-time when studies are being undertaken and 
full-time  when  reviewing  sector  studies,  during  and  while  organizing  the  workshops  and 
seminars, and while preparing the overview study. In particular, the consultant will do the 
following: 
(i)  Coordinate and supervise the activities of other consultants (ICRIER, IPPS-PU, 
and national consultants) and oversee the TA’s implementation to ensure its 
timely completion. 
(ii)  Assess the robustness of research methodology and the adequacy of work, as 
well as provide appropriate research guidance in order to enhance quality and 
coverage. 
(iii)  Assist in the mid-term review of all sector studies. 
(iv)  Review the draft final reports of all sector studies and the overview reports while 
providing  detailed  comments  for  further  revision,  if  required,  to  meet  the 
coverage and quality standards as well as to bring the reports up to publishable 
standards. 
(v)  Based on the TA’s Phase 1 findings, prepare a concise analytical overview to 
summarize TA findings and draw inferences from the development experience of 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and India for other developing member 
countries and middle-income countries in Asia and the Pacific. 
(vi)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as required. 
(vii)  Submit regular reports on the TA’s progress as agreed.   
2.  Institute of Public Policy Studies of Peking University (IPPS-PU)  
2.  The Institute is responsible to take the lead role in conducting the overview and the 
in-depth sector studies based on India’s recent development experience. Detailed terms of 
reference for the sector studies and the collaboration framework with the Indian institution will 
be finalized during the scoping workshop. The IPPS-PU will do the following: 
(i)  Take  the  lead  role  in  preparing  the  studies  under  the  regional  technical 
assistance (RETA) with a view to promoting future cooperation between the PRC 
and India in the sectors and areas selected for study. 
(ii)  Conduct  in-depth  studies  in  India  in  four  strategic  areas  of  interest  to  the 
Government of the PRC and an overview study on India’s reform experience in 
accordance with the terms of reference agreed during the scoping workshop.

Appendix 3  9 
(iii)  Collaborate with ICRIER in a sprit of international cooperation to facilitate ICRIER 
in carrying out its work in the PRC on four sectors of strategic interest to the 
Government of India. 
(iv)  Provide  necessary  research  assistance,  background  information,  and  data 
required  for  the  studies.  Moreover,  make  academic  facilities  and  faculty 
resources  available  to  Indian  counterparts  during  the  entire  course  of  the 
program of studies in accordance with the collaboration framework agreed during 
the scoping workshop. 
(v)  Institute  an  effective  internal  supervisory  arrangement  to  regularly  monitor 
progress of studies and their quality. 
(vi)  Participate in all TA activities in accordance with the implementation schedule 
agreed during the scoping workshop and conduct the final workshop in the PRC. 
2.  Indian Council for Research and International Economic Relations (ICRIER) 
3.  The Council is responsible to take the lead role in conducting the overview and the 
in-depth sector studies based on the PRC’s recent development experience. Detailed terms of 
reference for the sector studies and the collaboration framework with the PRC institution will be 
finalized during the scoping workshop. ICRIER will do the following: 
(i)  Take the lead role in preparing the studies under the RETA with a view to 
promoting future cooperation between the PRC and India in the sectors and 
areas selected for study. 
(ii)  Conduct in-depth studies in the PRC in four strategic areas of interest to the 
Government of India and an overview study on India’s reform experience in 
accordance with the terms of reference agreed during the scoping workshop. 
(iii)  Collaborate with IPPS-PU in a sprit of international cooperation to facilitate IPPS-
PU in carrying out its work in India on four sectors of strategic interest to the 
Government of the PRC. 
(iv)  Provide  necessary  research  assistance,  background  information,  and  data 
required  for  the  studies.  Moreover,  make  academic  facilities  and  faculty 
resources available to PRC counterparts during the entire course of the program 
of studies in accordance with the collaboration framework agreed during the 
scoping workshop. 
(v)  Institute  an  effective  internal  supervisory  arrangement  to  regularly  monitor 
progress of studies and their quality. 
(vi)  Participate in all TA activities in accordance with the implementation schedule 
agreed during the scoping workshop and conduct the final workshop in India.

10  Appendix 3 
 
B.  National Consultants 
1.  Coordination Specialist (7 person-months) 
1.  Responsible  for  assisting  ADB  and  the  international  development  specialist  in 
coordinating and supervising all activities under the TA. The consultant will provide inputs 
intermittently and/or part-time, as required, including the following. 
(i)  Assist ADB and the international development specialist in coordinating all activities 
under the TA. This includes liaising with participating institutions and helping to 
monitor TA progress and its administration. 
(ii)  Assist in the organization of seminars and workshops under the TA by taking care of 
all  logistic  arrangements,  including  travel,  hotel  reservations,  and  venue 
arrangements. 
(iii)  Assist ADB and the development specialist in the preparation, dissemination and 
publication of TA outputs.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  FDI  –  foreign direct investment 
  ICRIER  –  Indian Council for Research and International Economic 
Relations  
  IPPS-PU  –  Institute of Public Policy Studies of Peking University 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management   
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth, inclusive social development, and 
regional cooperation 
Subthemes  –  Promoting economic efficiency and enabling environment, human 
development, and trade and investment 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.
